DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of image method or procedure submitted.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic._Submitted; referred for judgment or consideration.

Concepts.definition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

Property.preferredDefinition: Submitted; referred for judgment or consideration.

Concepts.definition: The act of referring for judgment or consideration by others; the act of handing over something.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

DataElementConcept.origin: ACRIN:American College of Radiology Imaging Network
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 7/23/15 released as part of the 3Q2015 draft content review/TT_3/8/12 Curated for Core Lab QC.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the type of image method or procedure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

PermissibleValues.value: CT scan of upper abdomen, including the liver and adrenal glands
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: CT scan of upper abdomen, including the liver and adrenal glands

ValueMeaning.preferredName: CT scan of upper abdomen, including the liver and adrenal glands
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The superior portion of the abdomen.: Including the stated limits.: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex).: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: The superior portion of the abdomen.
Including the stated limits.

A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.

A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex).
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Both PET/CT scan and CT scan

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Both PET/CT scan and CT scan

It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.: One and the other; relating to or being two in conjunction.

Concepts.longName: Positron Emission Tomography and Computed Tomography Scan
Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that uses a small dose of a radioactive chemical (isotope) called a tracer that can detect sites of cancer growth, trauma, infection or degenerative disorders. The tracer, which is either injected into a vein or swallowed, travels through the bloodstream to the target organ, and emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera and analyzed by a computer to form an image of the target organ.

Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that uses a small dose of a radioactive chemical (isotope) called a tracer that can detect sites of cancer growth, trauma, infection or degenerative disorders. The tracer, which is either injected into a vein or swallowed, travels through the bloodstream to the target organ, and emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera and analyzed by a computer to form an image of the target organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

Concepts.definition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (en-DAHS-ko-pee) The use of a thin, lighted tube (called an endoscope) to examine the inside of the body.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or therapeutic procedure in which an endoscope is inserted in a tubular organ to examine the structural architecture and/or remove abnormal tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An x-ray image of the lymphatic system using a radiopaque imaging agent.

Concepts.definition: An x-ray image of the lymphatic system using a radiopaque imaging agent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging examination of the breast by means of x-rays.

Concepts.definition: A type of radiography used specifically to examine breast tissue. The procedure utilizes a low-dose of x-rays or radiation to generate an image. A mammography exam or mammogram, is used as a screening tool to detect early breast cancer in women experiencing no symptoms and to detect and diagnose breast disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique in which sound waves are sent out by an ultrasound probe that has been inserted in the vagina and a computer uses the ultrasound echoes to create an image of the female genital tract. The test can be performed to evaluate women with infertility problems, abnormal bleeding, sources of unexplained pain, congenital malformations of the uterus and ovaries, and possible tumors and infection.

Concepts.definition: A technique in which sound waves are sent out by an ultrasound probe that has been inserted in the vagina and a computer uses the ultrasound echoes to create an image of the female genital tract. The test can be performed to evaluate women with infertility problems, abnormal bleeding, sources of unexplained pain, congenital malformations of the uterus and ovaries, and possible tumors and infection.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

Concepts.definition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of high-energy radiation.  In low doses, x-rays are used to diagnose diseases by making pictures of the inside of the body.  In high doses, x-rays are used to treat cancer.

Concepts.definition: Ionizing electromagnetic radiation having a wavelength that is shorter than ultraviolet radiation and longer than gamma radiation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

Concepts.definition: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.
High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An x-ray examination of the chest.

Concepts.definition: An x-ray examination of the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of ultrasound imaging in which the ultrasound probe is pressed against the skin of the abdomen in order to create an image of the abdominal organs.

Concepts.definition: A method of ultrasound imaging in which the ultrasound probe is pressed against the skin of the abdomen in order to create an image of the abdominal organs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The portion of the body that lies between the thorax and the pelvis.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: The cavity located between the lungs and pelvis. It contains the lower esophagus, stomach, pancreas, intestines, liver, gallbladder and spleen.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure used to detect fractures, tumors, or degenerative conditions of the bone.

Concepts.definition: A procedure used to detect fractures, tumors, or degenerative conditions of the bone.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radioconjugate comprised of the small peptide apcitide labeled with the gamma-emitting technetium TC99m (metastable Tc-99). Apcitide binds to platelet glycoprotein (GP) GPIIb/IIIa receptors on the surface of activated platelets. Labeling apcitide with TC99m allows localization of thrombus formation by gamma-ray imaging equipment and the ability to distinguish between old, inactive thrombi and new, active thrombi.

Concepts.definition: A radioconjugate comprised of the small peptide apcitide labeled with the gamma-emitting technetium TC99m (metastable Tc-99). Apcitide binds to platelet glycoprotein (GP) GPIIb/IIIa receptors on the surface of activated platelets. Labeling apcitide with TC99m allows localization of thrombus formation by gamma-ray imaging equipment and the ability to distinguish between old, inactive thrombi and new, active thrombi.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Gamma Camera Iodine I 131 Metaiodobenzylguanidine Diagnostic Imaging

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Gamma Camera Iodine I 131 Metaiodobenzylguanidine Diagnostic Imaging
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An instrument used in medicine to produce images of internal organs after the injection of a radioactive drug into the body, where the drug releases gamma rays. It is used especially in medical diagnostic scanning. (Encarta Dictionary and Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary): An I 131 radioiodinated synthetic analogue of the neurotransmitter norepinephrine. Meta-iodobenzylguanidine localizes to adrenergic tissue and, in radioiodinated forms, may be used to image or eradicate tumor cells that take up and metabolize norepinephrine.: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation..

Concepts.definition: An instrument used in medicine to produce images of internal organs after the injection of a radioactive drug into the body, where the drug releases gamma rays. It is used especially in medical diagnostic scanning. (Encarta Dictionary and Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary)

An I 131 radioiodinated synthetic analogue of the neurotransmitter norepinephrine. Iobenguane localizes to adrenergic tissue and, in radioiodinated forms, may be used to image or eradicate tumor cells that take up and metabolize norepinephrine.
Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image of blood vessels.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that uses sound waves to measure characteristics of disturbed bood flow, such as direction, velocity and turbulence. This enables the examiner to differentiate between normal and abnormal flow patterns and, in some cases, to quantitate those characteristics that are helpful in determining the severity of abnormal flow states.

This enables the examiner to differentiate between normal and abnormal flow patterns and, in some cases, to quantitate those characteristics that are helpful in determining the severity of abnormal flow states.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Measuring the optical density of a substance by shining light on it and measuring its transmission.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image of the heart produced by ultrasonography.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A magnetic resonance imaging modality that uses a gradient echo pulse sequence with data acquisition after an initial 180 degree preparation pulse for contrast enhancement. TFE provides contrast at shorter echo times and acquisition times, thus reducing related image artifacts.

Concepts.definition: A magnetic resonance imaging modality that uses a gradient echo pulse sequence with data acquisition after an initial 180 degree preparation pulse for contrast enhancement. TFE provides contrast at shorter echo times and acquisition times, thus reducing related image artifacts.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A magnetic resonance imaging modality that offers rapid imaging time, easy reconstruction of any plane, and three-dimensional surface contour rendering with cut away postprocessing. Especially useful for imaging brain, MP-RAGE captures high tissue contrast and provides high spatial resolution with whole brain coverage in a short scan time.

Concepts.definition: A magnetic resonance imaging modality that offers rapid imaging time, easy reconstruction of any plane, and three-dimensional surface contour rendering with cut away postprocessing. Especially useful for imaging brain, MP-RAGE captures high tissue contrast and provides high spatial resolution with whole brain coverage in a short scan time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A magnetic resonance imaging modality that uses acquisition in the steady state with semi-random changes in the phase of the radio frequency pulses to produce a spatially independent phase shift. This optimizes the signal-to-noise ratio to provide high resolution and a decrease in the partial volume phenomenon.

Concepts.definition: A magnetic resonance imaging modality that uses acquisition in the steady state with semi-random changes in the phase of the radio frequency pulses to produce a spatially independent phase shift. This optimizes the signal-to-noise ratio to provide high resolution and a decrease in the partial volume phenomenon.

PermissibleValues.value: T2 and Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery MRI
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: T2 and Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery MRI

ValueMeaning.preferredName: T2 and Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery MRI
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A magnetic resonance imaging modality that uses an inversion-recovery pulse sequence to nullify the signal from fluids.

Concepts.longName: T2 and Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery MRI
Concepts.definition: A magnetic resonance imaging modality that uses an inversion-recovery pulse sequence to nullify the signal from fluids.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.7.24 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002644. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for scanning bone and measuring bone mineral density (BMD). A DXA scanner produces 2 X-ray beams, each with different energy levels. One beam is high energy while the other is low energy. The amount of x-rays that pass through the bone is measured for each beam. This will vary depending on the thickness of the bone. Based on the difference between the 2 beams, the bone density can be measured.

Concepts.definition: A technique for scanning bone and measuring bone mineral density (BMD). A DXA scanner produces 2 X-ray beams, each with different energy levels. One beam is high energy while the other is low energy. The amount of x-rays that pass through the bone is measured for each beam. This will vary depending on the thickness of the bone. Based on the difference between the 2 beams, the bone density can be measured.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Post Gadolinium T1-Weighted Magnetic Resonance Imaging

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Post Gadolinium T1-Weighted Magnetic Resonance Imaging
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.: An element with atomic symbol Gd, atomic number 64, and atomic weight 157.25.: A method of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that creates contrast between tissues based on differences in the longitudinal relaxation of a tissue's net magnetization vector; it measures the time taken for spinning protons to realign with the external magnetic field. This MRI sequence is produced by using short  time to echo (TE) and repetition times (TR).

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
An element with atomic symbol Gd, atomic number 64, and atomic weight 157.25.

A method of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that creates contrast between tissues based on differences in the longitudinal relaxation of a tissue's net magnetization vector; it measures the time taken for spinning protons to realign with the external magnetic field. This MRI sequence is produced by using short  time to echo (TE) and repetition times (TR).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates that an assessment was not performed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radiopharmaceutical containing methylene diphosphonate (medronate; MDP) complexed with the gamma-emitting radionuclide technetium Tc 99m with radioisotopic activity and hydroxyapatite affinity. Upon intravenous administration, skeletal uptake of technetium Tc 99m methylene diphosphonate occurs as a function of skeletal blood flow and osteogenic activity. The MDP moiety of this agent has affinity for hydroxyapatite crystals in bone with abnormal accumulation at sites with increased osteoid mineralization; labeling of MDP with Tc 99m allows scintigraphic imaging of areas of abnormal osteogenesis associated with malignant bone lesions.

Concepts.definition: A radiopharmaceutical containing methylene diphosphonate (medronate; MDP) complexed with the gamma-emitting radionuclide technetium Tc 99m with radioisotopic activity and hydroxyapatite affinity. Upon intravenous administration, skeletal uptake of technetium Tc 99m methylene diphosphonate occurs as a function of skeletal blood flow and osteogenic activity. The MDP moiety of this agent has affinity for hydroxyapatite crystals in bone with abnormal accumulation at sites with increased osteoid mineralization; labeling of MDP with Tc 99m allows scintigraphic imaging of areas of abnormal osteogenesis associated with malignant bone lesions.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Computed Tomography Or Magnetic Resonance Imaging Chest

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Computed Tomography Or Magnetic Resonance Imaging Chest
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.
